qas.question: Who created the safety elevator in 1852?
What feature did the safety elevator display?

answers.text: prevented the fall of the cab if the cable broke

qas.question: What did the govenor device engage to lock the elevator?
At what location was it first presented?

answers.text: New York exposition in the Crystal Palace

qas.question: Where was the first safety elevator installed?

context: In 1852, <a0_0>Elisha Otis<a0_0/> introduced the safety elevator, which <a1_0>prevented the fall of the cab if the cable broke<a1_0/>. The design of the Otis safety elevator is somewhat similar to one type still used today. A governor device engages <a2_0>knurled roller(s)<a2_0/>, locking the elevator to its guides should the elevator descend at excessive speed. He demonstrated it at the <a3_0>New York exposition in the Crystal Palace<a3_0/> in a dramatic, death-defying presentation in 1854, and the first such passenger elevator was installed at <a4_0>488 Broadway in New York City<a4_0/> on March 23, 1857.
